clinical_study.official_title: Aerobic Exercise Intervention in Acute Recovery Phase After Concussion: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the efficacy of aerobic exercise in the acute phase of recovery for pediatric patients with a concussion. Half of participants will complete sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise and half of participants will complete a placebo stretching protocol.

detailed_description.textblock: The safety of aerobic exercise in the management of pediatric patients with post-concussion syndrome (PCS) has been established, but there is no existing data on exercise treatment for pediatric patients in the acute phase of recovery after sports-related concussion. While intensive exercise too soon after concussion has been associated with delayed recovery and used to justify prolonged periods of rest, recent studies have shown that controlled, sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise may aid recovery by improving autonomic balance and cerebral blood flow auto-regulation after concussion. This study will randomly assign pediatric patients with concussion to a treatment group in which they will complete sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise or to a placebo group in which they will complete a standardized stretching protocol. All participants will have routine clinical visits that consist of a physical examination and exercise test, which will be terminated with the exacerbation of symptoms.

primary_outcome.description: Recovery is defined as symptom resolution, ability to exercise to exhaustion without symptom exacerbation, and clearance from clinician based on normal physical examination

arm_group.description: Aerobic exercise participants will receive an exercise prescription based on their heart rate threshold (HRT) for symptom exacerbation during an initial treadmill test. Participants will be asked to exercise once a day at 80% of their assigned HRT for up to 20 minutes depending on their age. Participants will wear a heart rate monitor to track their frequency, duration, and heart rate during aerobic exercise. The treatment will continue until the participant is fully recovered from their concussion, as determined by exercise tolerance and a normal symptom count and clinical examination.

Stretching exercise participants will receive a prescription to complete a standardized stretching protocol used commonly in physical therapy once a day for up to 20 minutes depending on their age. Participants will wear a heart rate monitor to track their frequency, duration, and heart rate during the stretching exercise. The treatment will continue until the participant is fully recovered from their concussion, as determined by exercise tolerance and a normal symptom count and clinical examination.

intervention.description: Participants will be given a prescription to exercise at 80% of their threshold heart rate for symptom exacerbation. Heart rate threshold will be monitored weekly in order to increase exercise level accordingly.
Participants will be given a prescription to complete a standardized stretching protocol.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pediatric patient within 10 days of sports-related concussion
Exclusion Criteria:
- Evidence of moderate or severe traumatic brain injury (TBI)
- Inability to exercise because of orthopaedic injury or increased cardiac risk
- Concurrent participation in other exercise for duration of study
- Inability to speak English
